content.description:
Climb the inviting crack (mostly hands), and finish by pulling over a roof that is easier than it looks from the ground. Save a #4 for the top.

To descend, continue upward to the top of the formation, and find a deep slot running toward Reynolds Hill. Descend the slot, and do an exposed but easy traverse left around the corner to the two bolt anchor at the top of Granite Staircase, a 5.11b sport climb. Some may want a rope to reach this anchor. From the base of the rappel, it's a short scramble back to your packs.
content.protection: Cams to BD #4 with emphasis on big hands.
content.location: It is on the Eastern end of the north side of Granite Staircase. An obvious crack leads to a roof.

content.description:
This crack system has a lot of variety. Plug in some gear, and fire the cruxy starting sequence to reach a bomber #1 jam. The crack quickly widens to big hands and passes a few very brief offwidth bits before easing off. Take a breather, and tackle the final short 0.75 crack.

To descend, continue upward to the top of the formation, and find a deep slot running toward Reynolds Hill. Descend the slot, and do an exposed but easy traverse left around the corner to the two bolt anchor at the top of Granite Staircase, a 5.11b sport climb. Some may want a rope to reach this anchor. From the base of the rappel, it's a short scramble back to your packs.
content.protection: Cams to at least #4. The #5 is probably optional, but I had one along and did place it.
content.location:
It is on the East end of the north side of Granite Staircase. Look for a crack that has a thin start and another crack coming in from the left to join it 20 feet from the ground. This is the next crack left of

Top Flight

.
